awd_titl_txt: Manufacturing USA: Computational Screening of Metal Oxides for Alkane Dehydrogenation to Olefins
awd_abstract_narration:
A promising route to olefins that are important building blocks for the chemical industry is the
dehydrogenation of alkanes on metal oxides. This reaction occurs due to oxide acid-base surface functionalities, but the underlying mechanism is poorly understood. This knowledge gap has been impeding efforts to design active and robust catalysts that efficiently convert natural gas (i.e. light hydrocarbons) to value-added chemicals (i.e. olefins), optimize natural gas upgrading, and reduce the cost of the energy-demanding dehydrogenation chemistries. The proposed research aims to fill this knowledge gap by elucidating structure-activity relationships on metal oxide catalysts applicable to the dehydrogenation of light alkanes, using first-principles-based computational techniques and experimental verification through collaboration with researchers from the RAPID Manufacturing Institute. The project has the potential to positively impact the chemical industry by accelerating catalyst discovery for the efficient conversion of light hydrocarbons from natural gas to value-added chemicals. The development of efficient processes that reduce the energy input and associated cost for chemicals production, and utilize the abundant natural gas reserves, can have a positive impact on society and the US economy.

The proposed research plan includes application of periodic Density Functional Theory calculations, ab-initio molecular dynamics simulations, multi-scale process modeling and machine learning to develop novel structure-activity relationships that describe the alkane dehydrogenation activity as a function of the Lewis acid-base properties of the oxides. These relationships will enable the rapid screening of a wide range of metal oxides, different facets on each oxide and a gamut of surface acid-base sites, to identify the prevailing dehydrogenation mechanism and the most active sites on the metal oxides, as function of their Lewis acid-base strength. The project will also create poisoning maps by identifying which surface sites will be poisoned by strong species adsorption, even at elevated dehydrogenation temperatures, and will study catalyst surface dynamics under realistic experimental conditions. The ultimate objective is to advance catalyst discovery by avoiding trial-and-error experimentation in the laboratory, address knowledge gaps pertinent to process intensification, and support translational research being conducted in the RAPID Manufacturing Institute. The educational and outreach components of the proposal include: (a) engaging graduate and undergraduate students in research, with a focus on students from under-represented backgrounds, (b) generating material for relevant courses (Chemical Kinetics, Catalysis, etc.) and (d) enabling STEM outreach to K-12 students through the Carnegie Science Center and University of Pittsburgh's INVESTING NOW program. Students will be trained on computational chemistry, molecular simulations, catalysis, process intensification, scientific computation, machine learning and high-performance computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Olefins are important chemical building blocks for the manufacturing of high value products. The ever-increasing demand for light olefins requires diversification from traditional oil-based cracking processes, known for high energy consumption, use of nonrenewable fossil fuels, and substantial CO2 emissions. Leveraging the abundance of light alkanes in shale gas, catalytic nonoxidative dehydrogenation of shale-gas-derived alkanes to light olefins can offer an energy-efficient and environmental friendly alternative route to olefins production. The search for active, selective, and robust catalysts plays a crucial role in mitigating the energy input required in the dehydrogenation processes. Despite significant research efforts devoted to alkane dehydrogenation, there is no systematic approach to screening dehydrogenation catalysts. In this project we applied first-principles-based multiscale simulations to construct novel alkane dehydrogenation structure-activity relationships on heterogeneous catalysts with Lewis acid-base surface properties (e.g. metal oxides and nitrides). In addition, we elucidated very complex hydrocarbon dehydrogenation mechanisms on metal oxides and metal nitrides and demonstrated doping routes to enhance catalytic activity. This computational work guides experimental efforts by identifying active dehydrogenation catalysts for industrial applications, offering a catalyst discovery roadmap and saving human labor and resources.

Research Outcomes: The project introduced novel structure-activity relationships to systematically assess the performance of metal oxides in the dehydrogenation of light alkanes to valuable olefins. The dehydrogenation models capture the catalyst acid–base surface properties (through dissociated H2 binding energy) and alkane substitution (through carbenium ion stability). While initially developed and applied to metal oxides, these relationships were successfully extended to metal nitrides showing universality in capturing the acid-base properties of the catalysts. The developed models were used to evaluate the activity of novel, previously untested metal nitride catalysts, unraveling the potential application of aluminum nitride as an efficient dehydrogenation catalyst for the conversion of light alkanes into valuable olefins. Additionally, the first-principles-based multiscale computational framework we built on this project, elucidated very complex hydrocarbon dehydrogenation mechanisms and highlighted the importance of applying multiscale tools to identify the preferred dehydrogenation mechanism. Besides developing kinetic models for alkane dehydrogenation, we introduced global and local connectivity as reactivity descriptors for hydrogen interaction with metal oxides, enabling high-throughput materials screening for energy storage applications and beyond. Additionally, we developed accurate thermodynamic reaction models for high temperature catalytic applications (including dehydrogenation, pyrolysis, etc.). Concepts and tools developed from this research significantly advance catalyst discovery applications by avoiding trial-and-error experimentation in the lab. Research results from this project have been published in more than a dozen of scientific articles and publicly shared on GitHub.  

Broader Impacts: The project contributed to the training of three PhD students and one postdoctoral researcher on first principles calculations, microkinetic modeling, kinetic Monte Carlo simulations, graph theory, and machine learning. On the educational aspects of the project, kinetic models for alkane dehydrogenation (microkinetic modeling codes) have been developed for chemical kinetics courses. On the educational outreach, graduate students have participated in a series of outreach activities at Pittsburgh’s Carnegie Science Center by designing and demonstrating simple chemistry experiments to high and middle school students. Additionally, presentation materials and video animations were developed to elucidate complex catalysis concepts, including catalytic alkane dehydrogenation mechanisms. Results from this research have the potential to impact other areas beyond Catalysis, such as Materials Science, Physics, Chemistry, Energy, and the Environment. Examples include energy-storage applications (e.g. hydrogen storage and batteries) and plastics decomposition and conversion into valuable chemicals enabling circular economy.
